case_name: Radhey Shyam Sharma v. Post Master General

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 208 of 1963 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 208 of 1963Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the en- forcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 23, 1964 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: March 23, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Con- stitution.

facts.text: Petitioner appointed as a Telegraphist by the Post Master General Nagpur in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was appointed as a Telegraphist by the Post Master General Nagpur in 1949. In July 1960. he was serving as an officiating Teleprinter Supervisor at Jaipur.

facts.text: In July 1960, petitioner was serving as an officiating Teleprinter Supervisor at Jaipur.

anchor.surface_text: In July 1960. he was serving as an officiating Teleprinter Supervisor at Jaipur. The employees of the Posts and Telegraphs Department  hereinafter referred to as the Department  went on strike from the midnight of July 11, 1960 throughout India and there was a similar strike at Jaipur.

facts.text: Employees of Posts and Telegraphs Department went on strike from midnight of July 11, 1960 throughout India, including Jaipur.

anchor.surface_text: The employees of the Posts and Telegraphs Department  hereinafter referred to as the Department  went on strike from the midnight of July 11, 1960 throughout India and there was a similar strike at Jaipur.

facts.text: Petitioner was on duty on July 11, 1960 from 12 noon to 8 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was on duty on that day from 12 numbern to 8 p.m. He says that after his duty was over, he did number go home but went to the dormitory where he fell asleep as he was tired.

facts.text: After duty on July 11, 1960, petitioner went to dormitory, fell asleep, woke up at about 11:30 p.m., wanted to go home, but was arrested by police as one of the demonstrators in connection with the strike.

anchor.surface_text: He says that after his duty was over, he did number go home but went to the dormitory where he fell asleep as he was tired. At about 11-30 p.m. he woke up on hearing some numberse and discovered that it was very late and then he wanted to go home. But as he came out, he was arrested by the police on the ground that he was also one of the demonstrators, who were demonstrating outside in companynection with the strike.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested under Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance No. 1 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The arrest was made under the Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance, No. 1 of 1960,  hereinafter referred to as the Ordinance . On July 13, the petitioner was suspended on the ground that a criminal charge was pending against him in a criminal companyrt.

facts.text: Petitioner suspended on July 13, 1960 on ground that criminal charge pending.

anchor.surface_text: On July 13, the petitioner was suspended on the ground that a criminal charge was pending against him in a criminal companyrt. However, the criminal charge was withdrawn on July 18, 1960.

facts.text: Criminal charge against petitioner withdrawn on July 18, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: However, the criminal charge was withdrawn on July 18, 1960. On July 21, 1960, a charge-sheet was served on the petitioner in the following terms-

facts.text: Charge-sheet served on petitioner on July 21, 1960 alleging gross misconduct for taking part in demonstration in furtherance of strike on midnight of July 11, 1960, violating orders dated 8-7-1960 under Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: On July 21, 1960, a charge-sheet was served on the petitioner in the following terms- That Shri Radhey Shyam Sharma I C S Telegraphist, CTO Jaipur companymitted gross misconduct in that on the midnight of the 11th July 1960, he took part in a demonstration in furtherance of the strike of the P. T. Employees in violation of the orders dated 8-7-1960 issued by the Government of India under the Essential Services Maintenance Ordinance, 1960  1 of 1960  prohibiting strike in any postal, telegraph or telephone Service.

facts.text: Inquiry conducted by Post Master General, Central Services Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: An inquiry was made in the matter by the Post Master Gene- ral, Central Services Nagpur to whom it was transferred as the petitioner had been appointed by that officer.

facts.text: Enquiry officer found petitioner guilty of the charge.

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry officer found the petitioner guilty of the charge framed against him and thereupon a numberice was issued to him to show cause why the penalty of reduction in the time scale by three stages for a period of two years affecting the future increments be number imposed upon him.

facts.text: Show cause notice issued for penalty of reduction in time scale by three stages for two years.

anchor.surface_text: and thereupon a numberice was issued to him to show cause why the penalty of reduction in the time scale by three stages for a period of two years affecting the future increments be number imposed upon him. Thereafter the Post Master General after taking into account the explanation submitted by the petitioner to the show cause numberice ordered that the pay of the petitioner should be reduced in the time scale by three stages for a period of two years and on restoration the period of reduction was number to operate to postpone his future increments.

facts.text: Post Master General imposed penalty of reduction in pay by three stages for two years.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Post Master General after taking into account the explanation submitted by the petitioner to the show cause numberice ordered that the pay of the petitioner should be reduced in the time scale by three stages for a period of two years and on restoration the period of reduction was number to operate to postpone his future increments.

facts.text: Petitioner appealed to Director General, Posts and Telegraphs.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the petitioner filed an appeal to the Director General, Posts and Telegraphs. The Director General directed further evi- dence to be taken on certain lines before deciding the appeal.

facts.text: Director General directed further evidence to be taken, but no further evidence given by Department, appeal rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The Director General directed further evi- dence to be taken on certain lines before deciding the appeal. However, numberfurther evidence was given on behalf of the Department and the matter was re-submitted to the Director General as it was Finally, the Director General companysidered the whole matter on the merits and rejected the appeal.

facts.text: Central Government issued order dated July 8, 1960 under s.3 of Ordinance prohibiting strike in postal, telegraph or telephone service.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that on July 8, 1960, the Central Government had issued an order under s. 3 of the Ordinance prohibiting any strike in the Department.

facts.text: Petitioner was Secretary of the local union of the employees of the Department.

anchor.surface_text: So far as that is companycerned, the authorities had the following undisputed facts before them - The petitioner was the Secretary of the local union of the employees of the Department  1  1963 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 789.

facts.text: Petitioner's duty finished at 8 p.m. on July 11, 1960, but he stayed in dormitory till 11:30 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: On that day the petitioners duty finished at 8 p.m. and he should have numbermally gone home but he stayed on in the dormitory till 11-30 p.m. which was just half an hour before the strike was to companymence

facts.text: Demonstration held in connection with strike at 11:30 p.m. on July 11, 1960, half hour before strike commenced.

anchor.surface_text: The demonstration was held in companynection with the strike by the employees of the Department at 11-30 p.m. just half an hour before the strike was to companymence The petitioner took part in that demonstration and was actually arrested amongst the demonstrators.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested amongst the demonstrators.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner took part in that demonstration and was actually arrested amongst the demonstrators.

facts.text: Court finds there was evidence to prove charge against petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: If on these undisputed facts the authorities came to the companyclusion that the petitioner acted in furtherance of the strike which was to companymence half an hour later and was thus guilty of gross misconduct it cannot in our opinion be said that there was numberevidence on which the authorities companycerned companyld find the charge framed against the petitioner proved. -The companytention therefore that there was numberevidence on which the authorities companycerned companyld find the charge proved must-fail. We therefore dismiss the petition.

facts.text: Strike commenced at midnight of July 11, 1960 was illegal under s.3(4)(b) of Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: The strike therefore that started on the midnight of July 11, 1960 was an illegal strike in view of s. 3  4  b  of the Ordinance.

facts.text: Petition dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore dismiss the petition.

issues.text: whether the punishment imposed upon him is violative of his fundamental rights under Arts. 19(1)(a) and 19(1)(b) and should be quashed

anchor.surface_text: the present petition is a sequel to the order of the Director General, and the petitioner contends that the punishment imposed upon him is violative of his fundamental rights under Arts. 19 1  a  and 19  1   b  and should be quashed. Reliance is placed on his behalf on two cases of this Court

issues.text: whether ss. 3, 4 and 5 of the Ordinance are ultra vires, as they contravene sub-clauses (a) and (b) of Art. 19(1)

anchor.surface_text: Further it is contended that ss. 3, 4 and 5 of the Ordinance are ultra vires, as they contravene sub-clauses  a  and  b  of Art. 19  1 . Lastly, it is urged that in any case there was noevidence on which it could be found that the charge against the petitioner had been proved.

issues.text: The first question that arises is whether ss.3, 4 and 5 of the Ordinance are violative of any fundamental rights enshrined in the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The petition has been opposed on behalf of the Union of India and it is urged that the Ordinance is perfectly constitutional and does not violate any fundamental rights. It is further urged that the two cases relied upon by the petitioner are of noassistance to him, as they were concerned with R.4-A and Rule 4-B of the Central Civil Services  Conduct  Rules, 1955. Lastly it is urged that there was evidence on which the authorities concerned could find the charge proved against the petitioner. The first question that arises is whether ss.3, 4 and 5 of the Ordinance are violative of any fundamental rights en- shrined in the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is noforce in the contention that these provisions of the Ordinance violate the fundamental rights enshrined in sub- cls.  a  and  b  of Art. 19 1 . A perusal of Art. 19 1  shows that there is nofundamental right to strike

arguments.claim: there is no fundamental right to strike

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of Art. 19 1  shows that there is nofundamental right to strike, and all that the Ordinance provides is with respect to any illegal strike as provided in the Ordinance. This aspect has been elaborately discussed in the Bank Employees case

arguments.claim: no provision in the Ordinance restricts freedom of speech and expression or peaceful assembly

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Ordinance which in any way restricts freedom of speech and expression, no is there any provision therein which restricts any one from assembling peaceably and without arms. The Ordinance thus has nothing to do with restricting

arguments.claim: Parliament had the competence to make a law in the terms of the Ordinance

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that Parliament had the competence to make a law in the terms of the Ordinance and therefore the President had also the power to promulgate such an Ordinance.

arguments.claim: Kameshwar Prasad case related to conduct rules prohibiting demonstrations, not applicable here

anchor.surface_text: Kameshwar Prasads case  2  related to R. 4-A of the Bihar Government Servants Conduct Rules, 1956, which provided that nogovernment servant shall participate in any demonstration or resort to any form of strike

arguments.claim: O.K. Ghosh case concerned with CCS Conduct Rules 4-A and 4-B, not the Ordinance

anchor.surface_text: In O. K. Ghoshs case 3  this Court was concerned with r. 4-A and r. 4-B of the Central Civil Services  Conduct  Rules, 1955... That case did not deal with the Ordinance at all and the charge in that case did not seem to have been in the same terms

arguments.claim: charge is based entirely on the Ordinance, acting in furtherance of illegal strike under s.5

anchor.surface_text: We have already set out the charge framed against the petitioner. it will be seen that the charge is based entirely on the Ordinance and has no connection with rr. 4-A and 4-B... The charge against the petitioner was that he had acted in furtherance of the strike

arguments.claim: strike was illegal under s.3(4)(b) of the Ordinance

anchor.surface_text: The strike therefore that started on the midnight of July 11, 1960 was an illegal strike in view of s. 3  4  b  of the Ordinance.

arguments.claim: undisputed facts sufficient to prove charge of acting in furtherance of strike

anchor.surface_text: If on these undisputed facts the authorities came to the conclusion that the petitioner acted in furtherance of the strike which was to commence half an hour later and was thus guilty of gross misconduct it cannot in our opinion be said that there was noevidence

holdings.text: Sections 3, 4 and 5 of the Ordinance are not violative of fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(a) and 19(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no force in the contention that these provisions of the Ordinance violate the fundamental rights enshrined in sub- cls. a and b of Art. 19 1 . A perusal of Art. 19 1  shows that there is nofundamental right to strike, and all that the Ordinance provides is with respect to any illegal strike as provided in the Ordinance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinance targets illegal strikes only; no restriction on speech/expression or assembly; no fundamental right to strike as per precedent.

holdings.text: There is no fundamental right to strike under Article 19(1).

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of Art. 19 1  shows that there is nofundamental right to strike, and all that the Ordinance provides is with respect to any illegal strike as provided in the Ordinance. This aspect has been elaborately discussed in the Bank Employees case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of Art.19(1); follows All India Bank Employees Association precedent.

holdings.text: No provision in the Ordinance restricts freedom of speech and expression or right to assemble peaceably and without arms.

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Ordinance which in any way restricts freedom of speech and expression, nor is there any provision therein which restricts any one from assembling peaceably and without arms. The Ordinance thus has nothing to do with restricting

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis shows Ordinance deals only with illegal strikes, not speech or assembly.

holdings.text: No necessity to consider reasonable restrictions under Articles 19(2) and 19(3).

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance thus has nothing to do with restricting the fundamental rights enshrined in sub-cls. a and b of Art. 19 1 , and there is therefore no necessity of even considering whether the provisions of the Ordinance can be justified under cls. 2 and 3 of Art. 19.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since no direct restriction on Art.19(1)(a),(b) rights, no need for justification under saving clauses.

holdings.text: Parliament had competence to enact the Ordinance; it is valid.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that Parliament had the competence to make a law in the terms of the Ordinance and therefore the President had also the power to promulgate such an Ordinance. The competence of the legislature therefore being not in dispute

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed legislative competence; no violation of fundamental rights.

holdings.text: Kameshwar Prasad and O.K. Ghosh cases inapplicable as they concerned conduct rules, not the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Ordinance is valid. Learned counsel for the petitioner in this connection relies on two cases of this Court to which reference has already been made. Kameshwar Prasads case 2 related to R. 4-A of the Bihar Government Servants Conduct Rules

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction: prior cases invalidated conduct rules on demonstrations; here charge under Ordinance for acting in furtherance of illegal strike.

holdings.text: The charge against petitioner based entirely on Ordinance (acting in furtherance of illegal strike under s.5), valid and not violative of Art.19(1)(a),(b).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge pertains to illegal strike promotion, not protected speech/assembly; punishment follows valid Ordinance.

holdings.text: Strike commencing midnight July 11, 1960 illegal under s.3(4)(b) of Ordinance.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Government order under s.3; s.3(4)(b) declares post-order strikes illegal.

holdings.text: Undisputed facts provide sufficient evidence for authorities to find charge proved (petitioner acted in furtherance of illegal strike).

anchor.surface_text: If on these undisputed facts the authorities came to the conclusion that the petitioner acted in furtherance of the strike which was to commence half an hour later and was thus guilty of gross misconduct it cannot in our opinion be said that there was noevidence on which the authorities concerned could find the charge framed against the petitioner proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts: union secretary, stayed late till 11:30pm, arrested in demonstration 30min before illegal strike; reasonable basis for conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no force in the contention that these provisions of the Ordinance violate the fundamental rights enshrined in sub- cls. a and b of Art. 19 1 . A perusal of Art. 19 1  shows that there is nofundamental right to strike, and all that the Ordinance provides is with respect to any illegal strike as provided in the Ordinance.
We therefore dismiss the petition.

We therefore dismiss the petition.
